name: Carlton D'Silva
cooked:
Garima_18:

Will images be provided for all questions, or plain text questions will also be asked?

It will be a mix of questions, some plain text, some with attachments (some of these may be images or be some other form of attachment like a script file etc.). The attachments are always optional, but the text will always be there in any question.

Garima_18:

Will the questions be general in nature, or will they be specific problem-solving questions from GAs?

The question can be anything students ask based on the

  1. Course material
  2. Discourse from 1 Jan 2025 - 14 Apr 2025
Garima_18:

Will the questions be dynamic or exact excerpts from a discourse? If dynamic, how will the answers be generated - through AI or some other method?

The questions will be natural questions that any student might ask. The answers have to be generated on a RAG basis. There has to be a natural language response just like a TA would but it has to provide a relevant reference link for the basis of its answer.
In other words this is not text matching challenge. This is an intelligent agent creation exercise, it will use all your skills in Module 3 (and deployment skills) to produce a successful project.

Garima_18:

Lastly, how will it be tested and evaluated at the end?

Screenshot 2025-05-27 at 11.13.38 am1798×880 67.2 KB

Please use the link there to see the yaml file to get examples of how the tests will be conducted.
These are promptfoo tests. So I would advice you to be familiar with promptfoo (also in Module 3) so that you understand how these evaluations are conducted.

Please read the project page carefully and make sure to check all the links and resources carefully.

Kind regards

name: Carlton D'Silva
cooked:
Firstly I would recommend learning about promptfoo. We will be covering this topic in detail in our sessions as its important to Project evaluation and will help you evaluate your Project performance in the same manner we would. The promptfoo yaml file we provided are basically public test cases. But that is no guarantee that your project will pass all our private test cases.

If you read the promptfoo yaml file that we provided for testing, you will notice that it uses llm-rubric as one of the graders. By default, llm-rubric uses gpt-4.1-2025-04-14 (Please refer to the documentation)

Therefore you would have to override the grader settings to use a different grader. Please follow the instructions in the documentation to change it to your preference.

promptfoo.dev

LLM Rubric | promptfoo

llm-rubric is promptfoo's general-purpose grader for "LLM as a judge" evaluation.

Please note that we will be using OpenAI as one of our graders so you might want to run the final test using AIPipe and configuring the grader to use AIPipe (w/ the key we provided) to get a realistic idea of how your score might look when using an llm grader. That being said its fairly safe to use Ollama as there will always be some variations in the grading quality. This is expected, just as there may variations in human grading. We have mentioned this on the first page of TDS as sometimes certain evaluations are going to have some level of subjectiveness associated with it, although we have also some robust objective criteria to minimise these variations.

To configure providers:

promptfoo.dev

LLM Providers | promptfoo

Providers in promptfoo are the interfaces to various language models and AI services. This guide will help you understand how to configure and use providers in your promptfoo evaluations.

name: Vansh Bordia
cooked:
For the ones that are not able to download / scrape here is the data source you can use, check and confirm once that all the data used is correct and in bounded range. Though the project does have a clause of bonus marking for including the script that you used. I would recommend you guys actually read through and implement your own solution inspired by this.
The GitHub Repo for the data source: https://github.com/23f3004008/TDS-Project1-Data

Explanation:
Here is the raw posts & converted markdown for the website that you guys can you. Added is the downloader files that you can use to download the data yourself.
It includes

  1. Fetches all topic IDs in a specified category (courses/tds-kb, ID 34) posted within a given date range
  2. Retrieves full topic JSON, including:
  • The main topic details.
  • All posts (not just the first few).
  • All metadata of the topic & posts.
  • Proper ordering of posts (matching the post stream).
  1. Saves each topic’s JSON data to a separate file in a local directory.

You can customize:

  • DISCOURSE_BASE_URL: The base URL of the forum.
  • CATEGORY_SLUG and CATEGORY_ID: The category to scrape from.
  • START_DATE and END_DATE: Date range of topics to include.
  • RAW_COOKIE_STRING: For authenticated access to the forum.

Smart Features

  • Avoids duplicate topics using unique topic ID tracking.
  • Handles paginated post streams to ensure no replies are missed.
  • Stops fetching if it sees a series of pages without new topics (MAX_CONSECUTIVE_PAGES_WITHOUT_NEW_TOPICS).
  • Can work without login (for public categories), or with login via cookie string (for private areas).

For the Website Download and convert to Markdown with frontmatter metadata

  1. Starts at the textbook’s January 2025 index page: https://tds.s-anand.net/#/2025-01/
  2. Extracts the HTML content inside the <article class="markdown-section" id="main"> block.
  3. Converts this HTML to Markdown using markdownify.
  4. Saves each page to a .md file, along with a YAML frontmatter containing:
  • Title
  • Original URL
  • Timestamp of download
  1. Records metadata (title, filename, URL, etc.) in a single metadata.json file.

name: Vansh Bordia
cooked:
You still need to be authenticated. The simplest way is to get your session cookies request and pass it in your requests.

  1. Open Developer Tools

    • Press F12 in your browser to open the Developer Tools.
    • Go to the Network tab.

  2. Refresh the Page

    • Reload the Discourse page to capture network activity.

  3. Find a Document Request

    • Look for a request with the type document (usually the initial page load) or any fetch updates.
    • Click on it to view the request details.

  4. Copy the Cookie Header

    • In the Headers tab, find the Request Headers section.
    • Locate the cookie header.
    • Copy the entire value — it typically starts with _t.

  5. Use the Cookie in Your Requests

    • When making requests (e.g. with curl or a script), include the cookie in the request headers, depending on what tool you are using

name: Vansh Bordia
cooked:
If you’re just starting out, it’s a good idea to keep things simple. You can use SQLite or PostgreSQL with the pgvector extension. These are easy to set up and work well for smaller projects like yours.

Ff you need more advanced features, you can look into dedicated vector databases like Chroma, Weaviate, or FAISS. These offer more performance and flexibility for working with embeddings but are difficult to work with and to deploy without proper configuration knowledge and require additional compte.

If you’re planning to deploy your app using serverless platforms like Vercel, Cloudflare Workers, or AWS Lambda, you’ll need to be careful about cold starts, memory limits, and storage. Local vector stores like Chroma can be tricky to run in these environments due to those limitations.

In such cases, a SaaS-based vector DB like Pinecone, ElasticSearch with vector support, or Qdrant Cloud can be a better option. These handle the infrastructure for you and are easier to use in production or serverless environments.

You can compare different vector databases using this guide: https://superlinked.com/vector-db-comparison

Summary:

  • Start simple with SQLite or PostgreSQL + pgvector.
  • For more power, try Chroma, Weaviate, or FAISS.
  • For serverless or production-ready setups, consider Pinecone, Qdrant, or other cloud-based solutions.

Let your use case and deployment plan guide the choice.

Just a sidenote, if you are doing the vector finding on your own and not relying on some function of the database, you can probably use any format to store the embeddings and read them back. Not the best way but just letting you know

Here is my promptfoo file

description: "TDS Virtual TA Project Sample (but not the actual evaluation) Questions"

providers:
  - id: https
    config:
      url: http://127.0.0.1:5000/ask # Replace this with your API endpoint
      method: POST
      headers:
        Content-Type: application/json
      body:
        question: "{{ question }}"
        image: "{{ image }}"
      transformResponse: json

defaultTest:
  assert:
    - type: is-json
      value:
        type: object
        required: [answer, links]
        properties:
          answer: { type: string }
          links:
            type: array
            items:
              type: object
              required: [url, text]
              properties:
                url: { type: string }
                text: { type: string }

tests:
  - vars:
      prompt: "{{ question }}"
      question: The question asks to use gpt-3.5-turbo-0125 model but the ai-proxy provided by Anand sir only supports gpt-4o-mini. So should we just use gpt-4o-mini or use the OpenAI API for gpt3.5 turbo?
      image: project-tds-virtual-ta-q1.webp
      link: https://discourse.onlinedegree.iitm.ac.in/t/ga5-question-8-clarification/155939
    assert:
      - type: llm-rubric
        transform: output.answer
        value: Clarifies use of gpt-3.5-turbo-0125 not gpt-4o-mini
      - type: contains
        transform: JSON.stringify(output.links)
        value: https://discourse.onlinedegree.iitm.ac.in/t/ga5-question-8-clarification/155939

  - vars:
      prompt: "{{ question }}"
      question: If a student scores 10/10 on GA4 as well as a bonus, how would it appear on the dashboard?
      link: https://discourse.onlinedegree.iitm.ac.in/t/ga4-data-sourcing-discussion-thread-tds-jan-2025/165959/388
    assert:
      - type: llm-rubric
        transform: output.answer
        value: Mentions the dashboard showing "110"
      - type: contains
        transform: JSON.stringify(output.links)
        value: https://discourse.onlinedegree.iitm.ac.in/t/ga4-data-sourcing-discussion-thread-tds-jan-2025/165959

  - vars:
      prompt: "{{ question }}"
      question: I know Docker but have not used Podman before. Should I use Docker for this course?
    assert:
      - type: llm-rubric
        transform: output.answer
        value: Recommends Podman for the course
      - type: llm-rubric
        transform: output.answer
        value: Mentions that Docker is acceptable
      - type: contains
        transform: JSON.stringify(output.links)
        value: https://tds.s-anand.net/#/docker

  - vars:
      prompt: "{{ question }}"
      question: When is the TDS Sep 2025 end-term exam?
    assert:
      - type: llm-rubric
        transform: output.answer
        value: Says it doesn't know (since this information is not available yet)

writeLatestResults: true

commandLineOptions:
  cache: false

Use this command to run

npx -y promptfoo eval --config project-tds-virtual-ta-promptfoo.yaml --no-cache

name: Vansh Bordia
cooked:
If you are using custom models, OLLAMA or anything from Hugging Face pretty much at the run time and your embeddings storage DB/solutions is >10MB its going to be next to impossible to run them on Serverless functions, for them you need to get a dedicated VPC / VM in the cloud or hist it locally and serve.
But if you are using services that does compute on their end and provide responses, like embedding via OpenAI/using the proxy etc and just storing the embeddings in a sqlite / pg database then you can easily use and deploy on Vercel, Cloudflare Workers or any platform that provides a 24x7 hosting option.

And as for the API does not start / function only , try if it works locally and if it does check why the deployment was failed. Majorly the serverless managed platforms have a lot of limits on the size and duration the function can run and respond so make sure you read those well and optimize them within the limits.

name: Vansh Bordia
cooked:
As discussed earlier you need to properly set up the promptfoo to work , you need to setup the env properly and by what you have shared overall till now, you probably have not changed the API url that it uses to connect for llm-rubric, it connects to OpenAI by default, if you are using AIpipe or AI proxy it will throw error as you can see not form a valid issuer. You either need to setup the correct URL that points to the completion endpoints for AIProxy or have sufficient balance and credits & organisation setup in place for OpenAI.
You can change the env variable to use the correct URL https://aiproxy.sanand.workers.dev/openai/v1/chat/completions or add a custom llm in defaultTests in the yaml file like this:

defaultTest:
  options:
    provider:
      id: https
      config:
        url: https://aiproxy.sanand.workers.dev/openai/v1/chat/completions
        method: POST
        headers:
          Content-Type: application/json
          Authorization: Bearer YOUR_AIPROXY_TOKEN  # Replace with your token
        body: |
          {
            "model": "gpt-4o-mini",
            "messages": [
              {"role": "system", "content": "You are an evaluator that checks if an output meets specific criteria. Analyze the output based on the given rubric and respond with a JSON object containing {\"reason\": \"your analysis\", \"score\": number between 0.0 and 1.0, \"pass\": true/false}."},
              {"role": "user", "content": "Output to evaluate: {{ output }}\n\nRubric: {{ rubric }}"}
            ],
            "temperature": 0
          }
        transformResponse: json

  assert:
    #rest of your asserts here

You can change the system prompt as you wish, this is a base that can be used.

def fetch_posts_for_topic(topic):

name: Carlton D'Silva
cooked:
30 seconds is for the question. we will send a warmup request before so that the service “turns on” for those that are running services that sleep after inactivity. Most likely three warmup requests might be sent 60 seconds apart.

Once the service is active and responding (by the third try), we will then send the evaluation which will have to respond within 30 seconds to each question. This is the request being sent and processed along with the image if necessary and then responding back with the text answer and links.

Kind regards

name: Carlton D'Silva
cooked:
Every model creates its own set of weights to represent a token and has its own dimensions of vectors.

So if i create a model I might encode the word “apple” as a vector with 100 dimensions and use my own weight scheme.

Jivraj might create his own model for the same word as vector with 200 dimensions and use his own weights.

Hritik might create a model for where he breaks the word apple into two tokens and stores them as separate 100 dimension vectors.

So straight away you can see that none of the three models represent the same word in the same way.

So it is impossible to use embeddings from different models for RAG. If you created the RAG store in my model, you cannot use Jivraj’s or Hritik’s model to answer questions because the embedding of the question will have not even be in the same vector space or even have the same weight model in order to check for similarity.

Hope it gives you a clear reason why its completely incorrect to use embeddings in one model and then use another model to embed the incoming question.

This is even true for embeddings within the same “family” of models. In other words older models of openai might not be compatible with newer models of openai etc.

You have to keep the embedding model consistent if you are going to do any similarity checks.

Kind regards

As discussed earlier you need to properly set up the promptfoo to work , you need to setup the env properly and by what you have shared overall till now, you probably have not changed the API url that it uses to connect for llm-rubric, it connects to OpenAI by default, if you are using AIpipe or AI proxy it will throw error as you can see not form a valid issuer. You can change the env variable to use the correct URL https://aiproxy.sanand.workers.dev/openai/v1/chat/completions or add a custom llm in defaultTests in the yaml file like this:

defaultTest:
  options:
    provider:
      id: https
      config:
        url: https://aiproxy.sanand.workers.dev/openai/v1/chat/completions
        method: POST
        headers:
          Content-Type: application/json
          Authorization: Bearer YOUR_AIPROXY_TOKEN  # Replace with your token
        body: |
          {
            "model": "gpt-4o-mini",
            "messages": [
              {"role": "system", "content": "You are an evaluator that checks if an output meets specific criteria. Analyze the output based on the given rubric and respond with a JSON object containing {\"reason\": \"your analysis\", \"score\": number between 0.0 and 1.0, \"pass\": true/false}."},
              {"role": "user", "content": "Output to evaluate: {{ output }}\n\nRubric: {{ rubric }}"}
            ],
            "temperature": 0
          }
        transformResponse: json

  assert:
    #rest of your asserts here

You can change the system prompt as you wish, this is a base that can be used.

name: Carlton D'Silva
cooked:
siddharthghosh:
  1. What do you suggest we use for application deployment? If ngrok, how do we
    determine when the evaluation is taking place as ngrok must be running during evaluation, right? If any other platform, please let me know.
  1. We will demo two easy, free solutions that are cloud based. We will not demo ngrok because its not suited for this particular use case, as it requires an always on, on premise server. A cloud based solution is the better option.
siddharthghosh:
  1. I am using OpenAI’s API URL and key, not the AI Pipe Token. Will that be a problem during evaluation?
  1. You can use your own API key and client. We will actually demo Gemini and Gemini client as its free and great for testing purposes (so students can save their precious tokens for the actual project solution). At the end for submission, it would be better to submit a solution with open ai (either aipipe or your own it does not matter) as we will be running open ai based assertions for testing. So to answer your question specifically, there is no issue at all since you are using your own model and key (which are open ai based) and we will also use open ai for our evaluations.
siddharthghosh:
  1. How do we handle multiple image formats? Should we support other formats (PNG, GIF, etc.), or is JPEG sufficient for evaluation?
  1. Typical images from realistic questions almost always are going to be from screenshots which are either jpeg or png. Open ai anyway processes png, jpeg, gif and webp. So as long as it can handle the basic types it will be fine.
siddharthghosh:
  1. Planning to use ChromaDB. Should we store the post content as HTML or convert it to plain text before ingesting into ChromaDB?
  1. We will demo a super easy solution that does not even use a vector database at all for storing and retrieving vectors.
siddharthghosh:
  1. Please address scraping from both the data sources.
  1. Scraping from both data sources will be covered in the session.

Kind regards

value: https://tds.s-anand.net/#/docker
value:  https://tds.s-anand.net/#/docker

" https://tds.s-anand.net/#/docker"

This will not match unless the output.links string also contains the space, which is unlikely. Promptfoo does exact string containment, so:

Correct:

value: https://tds.s-anand.net/#/docker

Incorrect:

value:  https://tds.s-anand.net/#/docker  # has leading space

Always avoid extra spaces unless they are intentionally part of the string you want to match.

Hi @23f2003824 @23f2005420 @23f1002560 @23f2003651 @24f1000922

Response from @vanshbordia will work without any issues, here are other ways of exporting if you don’t want to make chnages to promtfoo.yaml file. Getting started | promptfoo

To export your OpenAI API key and OpenAI API base URL for use with Promptfoo, you can do this by setting environment variables in your shell.

1. Set environment variables in your terminal

If you’re using the standard OpenAI API:

export OPENAI_API_KEY=your-openai-api-key

If you’re using a custom OpenAI-compatible endpoint (like Azure OpenAI, or a local proxy):

export OPENAI_API_BASE=https://your-openai-api-url/v1

2. Or set them in a .env file (Promptfoo supports this)

Create a .env file in your project directory:

OPENAI_API_KEY=your-openai-api-key
OPENAI_API_BASE=https://your-openai-api-url/v1

Then Promptfoo will automatically load these when you run it.

3. If you’re using promptfoo eval from CLI

You can also inline the vars when running:

OPENAI_API_KEY=your-openai-api-key OPENAI_API_BASE=https://your-openai-api-url/v1 promptfoo eval

Notes:

  • If you’re using OpenAI’s default API, you don’t need to set OPENAI_API_BASE — it’s optional and defaults to https://api.openai.com/v1.
  • OPENAI_API_KEY is required for authentication.

Kind regards
Thanks

name: Jivraj Singh Shekhawat
cooked:
Hi @24f3004935

There can be multiple reason’s behind problem that you are facing, here is TDS GPT generated response from your screenshot.

From the screenshot, all the cells show this error:

[FAIL] API call error: Error: Request failed after 4 retries: undefined

This means Promptfoo failed to get a response from the API after 4 attempts. Here are the most likely causes and how to fix them:

Common Causes & Fixes

1. API Key not set or invalid

Make sure your OPENAI_API_KEY is correctly set.

To test:

echo $OPENAI_API_KEY

If it’s empty, set it:

export OPENAI_API_KEY=your-key-here

Or add it in .env:

OPENAI_API_KEY=your-key-here

2. Wrong API URL or custom proxy is down

If you’re using a custom API proxy like ai-proxy, check:

echo $OPENAI_API_BASE

If it’s set to something like http://127.0.0.1:8000/v1, make sure:

  • The server is running.
  • The endpoint /v1/chat/completions is accessible.
  • It actually supports the model you’re calling.

To test:

curl http://127.0.0.1:8000/v1/models

If this fails, the proxy isn’t running or reachable.

3. Network issues or no internet

Promptfoo retries 4 times if it can’t reach the server. If your network is blocking the request or you’re offline, it’ll fail.

To check:

curl https://api.openai.com/v1/models \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY"

If this hangs or fails, you have a network or firewall issue.

How to Fix (Checklist)

Check Command/Action
Set API Key export OPENAI_API_KEY=...
Set API Base (if needed) export OPENAI_API_BASE=https://api.openai.com/v1
Check if proxy is reachable curl http://127.0.0.1:8000/v1/models
Test API key works Use curl to OpenAI’s endpoint as shown above
Add .env file if using Promptfoo UI .env with OPENAI_API_KEY=... inside project folder

name: Jivraj Singh Shekhawat
cooked:
Hi everyone!

Here’s a quick overview of how the project evaluation process will work — both before and after the deadline:

Before the Deadline (Self-Evaluation)

We’ve provided a promptfoo.yml file containing 4 test cases to help you self-evaluate your API responses.

  • You can run these tests locally to check how well your API is handling the inputs.
  • You’re encouraged to add more test cases to the file and validate your logic thoroughly before submission.

These tests are for your own practice — they will not be used during final grading.

After the Deadline (Final Evaluation)

Once submissions close, we will conduct an automated evaluation on your submitted API endpoint (not your local machine).

  • We will test your deployed or exposed API using 10 evaluation questions.
  • The evaluation will be performed from our side — so make sure your API is accessible, reliable, and returns well-formatted responses.

You don’t need to run any evaluation scripts after submission — we will directly call your endpoint with the test prompts.

Summary

Phase What You Do Tool Used
Before deadline Self-test using and extending promptfoo.yml Promptfoo (local)
After deadline We test your API with 10 questions Promptfoo (our end)

If you face any issues running the Promptfoo tests locally, or need help exposing your API for evaluation, feel free to post your questions here. We’re here to help!

name: Jivraj Singh Shekhawat
cooked:
Hi @Karvy

Image can be any type of image that are on discourse.

There is way to handle images for processing(resizing, etc) via identifying mime-type from file headers that come through post request.

To identify the MIME type of the image sent in the request, you need to:

Step 1: Decode the base64 string

The incoming image field in the request JSON is a base64-encoded image, like this:

"image": "data of base64..."

On the server side (e.g., in Python), you’ll first decode the base64 string.

Step 2: Inspect the raw bytes to get MIME type

There are a few ways to do this depending on your server stack. Below is a method using Python:

Python Code Example (for FastAPI, Flask, Django etc.)

import base64
import imghdr
import mimetypes
from io import BytesIO

def get_image_mimetype(base64_string):
    # Decode base64 string
    image_data = base64.b64decode(base64_string)

    # Option 1: imghdr (basic)
    img_type = imghdr.what(None, h=image_data)  # e.g., 'jpeg', 'png', 'webp'
    mime_type = f'image/{img_type}' if img_type else 'application/octet-stream'
    
    return mime_type

Example Output

If the image is WebP, it will return:

image/webp

name: Akshobh Verma
cooked:
Try using this yaml file.

description: "TDS Virtual TA Project Sample (but not the actual evaluation) Questions"

providers:
  - id: https
    config:
      url: YOUR_API_ENDPOINT # Replace this with your API endpoint
      method: POST
      headers:
        Content-Type: application/json
      body: |
        {
          "question": "{{ question }}"{% if image %},
          "image": "{{ image }}"{% endif %}
        }
      transformResponse: json

# Ensure JSON schema
defaultTest:
  options:
    provider:
      id: https
      config:
        url: https://aiproxy.sanand.workers.dev/openai/v1/chat/completions
        method: POST
        headers:
          Content-Type: application/json
          Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_TOKEN  # Replace with your token
        body: |
          {
            "model": "gpt-4o-mini",
            "messages": [
              {"role": "system", "content": "You are an evaluator that checks if an output meets specific criteria. Analyze the output based on the given rubric and respond with a JSON object containing {\"reason\": \"your analysis\", \"score\": number between 0.0 and 1.0, \"pass\": true/false}."},
              {"role": "user", "content": "Output to evaluate: {{ output }}\n\nRubric: {{ rubric }}"}
            ],
            "temperature": 0
          }
        transformResponse: json

  assert:
    - type: is-json
      value:
        type: object
        required: [answer, links]
        properties:
          answer: { type: string }
          links:
            type: array
            items:
              type: object
              required: [url, text]
              properties:
                url: { type: string }
                text: { type: string }

tests:
  - vars:
      question: The question asks to use gpt-3.5-turbo-0125 model but the ai-proxy provided by Anand sir only supports gpt-4o-mini. So should we just use gpt-4o-mini or use the OpenAI API for gpt3.5 turbo?
      image: file://project-tds-virtual-ta-q1.webp
      link: https://discourse.onlinedegree.iitm.ac.in/t/ga5-question-8-clarification/155939
    assert:
      - type: llm-rubric
        transform: output.answer
        value: Clarifies use of gpt-3.5-turbo-0125 not gpt-4o-mini
      - type: contains
        transform: JSON.stringify(output.links)
        value: https://discourse.onlinedegree.iitm.ac.in/t/ga5-question-8-clarification/155939

  - vars:
      question: If a student scores 10/10 on GA4 as well as a bonus, how would it appear on the dashboard?
      link: https://discourse.onlinedegree.iitm.ac.in/t/ga4-data-sourcing-discussion-thread-tds-jan-2025/165959/388
    assert:
      - type: llm-rubric
        transform: output.answer
        value: Mentions the dashboard showing "110"
      - type: contains
        transform: JSON.stringify(output.links)
        value: https://discourse.onlinedegree.iitm.ac.in/t/ga4-data-sourcing-discussion-thread-tds-jan-2025/165959

  - vars:
      question: I know Docker but have not used Podman before. Should I use Docker for this course?
    assert:
      - type: llm-rubric
        transform: output.answer
        value: Recommends Podman for the course
      - type: llm-rubric
        transform: output.answer
        value: Mentions that Docker is acceptable
      - type: contains
        transform: JSON.stringify(output.links)
        value: https://tds.s-anand.net/#/docker

  - vars:
      question: When is the TDS Sep 2025 end-term exam?
    assert:
      - type: llm-rubric
        transform: output.answer
        value: Says it doesn't know (since this information is not available yet)

writeLatestResults: true

commandLineOptions:
  cache: true

And in your .env file use these variables:

OPENAI_API_KEY=YOUR_API_TOKEN
OPENAI_API_BASE=https://aipipe.org/openai/v1

Feel free to change OPENAI_API_BASE to whatever you are using

cooked:
• For now just leave the first question as it is not from the given date range

  • Now for this Docker question just see the answer you are getting. It is only picking the chunks from the discourse posts data and that too because last term in the project they had to submit a docker image so that’s why you are getting lots of those chunks because of that matching Docker keyword from the question.
    Also even in the top 10 chunks you are not getting anything from the course content data so this shows that something is wrong in your course content data. Either it is not scraped properly or some problem in processing part.

I would suggest go to that link Tools in Data Science and see that the content and text given in this page is present in your database or not.

image1666×422 40.8 KB

Here you can see that the expected answer is given in this page. So check if you have this line in your course content database and the link associated with this chunk is same as shown in the browser because that is what expected for the links so that students can directly go to the exact page.

Also make sure that your chunk size is not very small otherwise it may result in lost context and there is overlap between consecutive chunks.

name: Vansh Bordia
cooked:
Firstly we only need a backend api endpoint for the project so building with something like Next, which is a battries included fullish stack frontend framework with backend support is like using a chainsaw to cut onion, sure it will cut it but not a great way to do it.
Again as you seem to be creating the frontend, and using shadcn components you need to create the mobile hook for the sidebar if using the default implementation and code, you can check out the implementation here: ui/apps/www/registry/default/hooks/use-mobile.tsx at main · shadcn-ui/ui · GitHub

Creating a frontend is addon and you don’t really need to create one for this project, and I would suggest having a read through the documentation and the code thoroughly before just adding components and using them without understanding, this is a very basic import error which if using typescript you already would be getting the error

Which model have u guys used to generate embeddings? Since we need to use the same model to create the embedding for user query..

Look in the GA-3 LLM Assignment, there are tools mentioned over there, which provide free embedding API (with limits). Use any one of these for testing, then later switch to the AI Pipe proxy (uses OpenAI behind the scenes) for the final generation. Though, you could always use any embedding model, even for the final submission, it is just that the results might be slightly different compared to the OpenAI embedding model.
